conversation.content:
[shaky voice] They told me this morning, um, about the promotion. Supervisor. Me. [bitter] After three years packing boxes, I guess they figured I was—I don't know, management material or whatever. [pause] The thing is, they want me to, er, handle the restructuring. [very quietly] That's what they're calling it. Restructuring. [sarcastic] Such a clean word for it, right? 

[anxious] Miguel taught me everything, you know? Like, literally showed me how to hold the tape gun so my wrist wouldn't hurt after eight hours. [stuttering] And-and Rosa, she basically—I mean, she covered for me so many times when I was still figuring things out. [upset] Now I have to sit them down tomorrow, [clearing throat], look them in the eye and tell them their positions are being eliminated. 

[angry] Corporate says it's nothing personal, just numbers on a spreadsheet. [very sad] But Rosa's got three kids. Miguel's been here fifteen years—fifteen! [whispering] I keep thinking maybe I should just turn it down, but honestly, I need this. [regretful] My mom's medical bills are—anyway. [long pause]

[crying while speaking] How do I even start that conversation? Hey guys, remember when you taught me everything? [monotone] Well, thanks for that, here's your pink slip. [sniffle] God, I feel like such a—[trailing off] I don't even know what I am anymore.

subject: Getting promoted from packer to supervisor but having to lay off the crew that trained you
